title: Chipmunk Mountain
text:
Chipmunk Mountain is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in southwestern <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, Canada, located southwest of <a href="Bralorne%2C%20British%20Columbia">Bralorne</a>. It has an elevation of and a <a href="topographic%20prominence">topographic prominence</a> of , making it the highest point on an east-trending <a href="scree">scree</a>d ridge. This horn-like <a href="Rock%20pinnacle">rocky tower</a> is similar to <a href="The%20Black%20Tusk">The Black Tusk</a> in <a href="Garibaldi%20Provincial%20Park">Garibaldi Provincial Park</a>.
The mountain was named in 1920 by James Landsborough after a summit party had given lunch scraps to a <a href="chipmunk">chipmunk</a>.
Geology.
Chipmunk Mountain is the remains of an extinct volcano that formed during the <a href="Miocene">Miocene</a> epoch. The <a href="volcanic%20rock">volcanic rock</a>s comprising Chipmunk Mountain crop out in a area and consist of <a href="pyroclastic%20rock">pyroclastic rock</a>s, <a href="sill%20%28geology%29">sills</a> and <a href="dike%20%28geology%29">dikes</a>. These volcanic rocks range from <a href="basalt">basalt</a>s to <a href="rhyolite">rhyolite</a>s, with the majority classifying as <a href="basaltic%20andesite">basaltic andesite</a>s and <a href="andesite">andesite</a>s. They are closely related to the <a href="calc-alkaline">calc-alkaline</a> volcanic centres of the <a href="Pemberton%20Volcanic%20Belt">Pemberton Volcanic Belt</a>, indicating that the volcanic rocks comprising Chipmunk Mountain were created as a result of <a href="volcanism">volcanism</a> in the <a href="Canadian%20Cascade%20Arc">Canadian Cascade Arc</a>. The volcanic rocks have been dated to be million years old, which correlates with the time of Pemberton Belt volcanism.
